titlestmt.titleproper: Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights 1984-2003 GLBTQ.2012.07

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-12-01T15:29-0500

did.unittitle: Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, 1984-2003
did.abstract: The Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights (CCLGCR) was an organization prominent during the 1980’s and 1990’s for standing up for GLBTQ civil rights. They avidly fundraised, made a presence in political discussions and rallies, and created a safe zone for homosexuals in the state. This collection includes the group’s organizational documents, fundraising efforts, and newspaper articles, along with other related items.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights (CCLGCR) was formed during the summer of 1983 by a group of gay men and women discouraged by the continued defeat of the Gay Civil Rights Bill. They decided to form a statewide organization dedicated to the passage of civil rights legislation regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation. The coalition worked with progressive political organizations, other minority groups, religious affiliates, educators, and legal, social, and healthcare professionals to develop a lesbian and gay community. In 1985, the group established four regions throughout the state. In 1986, the group added “Connecticut” to the beginning of their name, becoming the CT CLGCR, in order to be able to back political candidates according to state law. The Political Action Committee was thus formed in 1988. The PAC interviewed candidates and reported the information back to the coalition, focusing mainly on areas of importance for homosexuals. The establishment of the PAC also led to inclusion in the statewide Legislative Electoral Action Program (LEAP), strengthening the CT CLGCR’s voice in the state government. Other projects initiated by CCLGCR were Stop the Hate and Love Makes a Family. In 1989, the group organized the HIV Task Force which was created to deal with legislative issues involving HIV and AIDS by writing position papers and making suggestions to the rest of the coalition. Another project was called The Anti-Violence Project, following the murder of a Connecticut gay man in 1988. Immediately following this incident, the AVP was created to monitor the murder case but also created Speak Out! in 1989. This program supplied organizations, school, and other interested parties with a participating speaker on homosexual issues. They also focused on the Hate Crimes Bill in 1990 pushing for its passage in conjunction with several other groups. The Religious Task Force was created in 1991 to organize the state’s religious community in support of the Gay Rights Bill. Later, the group changed its name to include transgender individuals, becoming CCLGBTCR. By 1999, the group was organized in six congressional districts and supported issues in the legislature such as anti-discrimination laws for students K-12, private right of action, health issues support such as HIV/AIDS and breast cancer, domestic partner benefits for state employees, and opposition to any state law prohibiting same gender marriage. In 2000, CCLGBTCR embarked on the Diversity Project to expand the membership base by meeting with diverse communities in the state, raise the level of awareness for the coalition, and assist communities in overcoming barriers that hinder their participation in the work of the coalition.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, 1984-2003 (GLBTQ.2012.07). GLBTQ Archives. Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection includes documents relating directly to the Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights in addition to articles, advertisements, and correspondence during the time period of 1984-2003.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: An oral history interview of Carolyn Gabel-Brett is available within the Digital Collections of the GLTBQ Archives on the website of the Elihu Burritt Library.

physdesc.extent: Materials in container 6 was forwarded to the Burritt Librar by Carolyn Gable Brett in August 2015.
